Jim Dixon wrote:

> The main point is that compilation is a lossy process.  When you write
> i++ it's succinct but very clear.  The compiler translates this into 
>   push variable
>   push 1
>   add
>   store variable
> While it's not impossible, it's difficult and expensive for a
> bytecode (re)compiler to sort out what's going on here and
> optimize back to the succintness of the original.

Hotspot doesn't need to "optimize it back to the original", it only
needs to replace it with optimized machine code.

I don't see what is difficult or expensive in finding the above and
replacing it with "inc variable" or something. And even if it were, it
only needs to be done once, so I don't care anyway. Hell, Hotspot even
can inline a non-final instance method as long as it isn't (yet)
overridden!

Take care, Ilja
